bioghist.p: Charles Godfrey Leland (1824-1903) was an American humorist and folklorist. Born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, he was educated at Princeton University, and in Europe. Leland worked in journalism, traveled extensively, and became interested in folklore and folk linguistics, publishing books and articles on American and European languages and folk traditions. he published a number of books, including Hans Breitmann's Ballads and Aradia, or the Gospel of the Witches. George Henry Boker (1823-1890) was a Philadelphia-based poet and playwright. He founded the Union League of Philadelphia in 1862 and held diplomatic appointments to Turkey and Russia. Leland and Boker, whose fathers were business partners, were close friends from childhood.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of 15 letters from Charles Godfrey Leland to George Henry Boker, 1861 and 1869-1870. Most of the letters were written during Leland's trip to Europe after he resigned from his position as Editor of the Philadelphia Press in 1868. The letters discuss the culture, literature, and social life he encountered during his trip abroad, and contain references to the two correspondents' acquaintances among the literary circles of both America and Europe. The collection includes a typescript of Sculley Bradley's introduction to and edited transcriptions of the collection of letters from the mid-1930s.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
